body: For the last five years, Cobble Hill has prospered with New York City, its stately brownstones drawing young couples to its quiet streets just blocks from downtown Brooklyn. This week, the Giuliani administration said that one of its landmarked blocks would be home to a new homeless shelter. In Cobble Hill, the reaction was furious. Residents and
title: Cobble Hill Denounces Plan for a Homeless Shelter

body: Multiplex movie theaters are a coming attraction in commercial real estate across the city for 1999, a prospect that has brought a degree of local unease about their effect on nearby residential neighborhoods. The Forest City Ratner Companies is not only planning a major multiplex in downtown Brooklyn, but is also building one in the Astoria
title: Commercial Real Estate; All Over Town, Movie Screens Are Popping Up

body: Thwarted by surging construction costs, Government officials have scaled back a long-stalled plan to expand the Federal courthouse in Brooklyn to bring it within the $194 million that Congress has appropriated for the project. As a result, instead of an addition that would be 18 stories tall and contain 24 courtrooms, the plan now calls for a
title: U.S. Courthouse Plan in Brooklyn Is Cut Back

body: MOSCOWITZ-Grover M. Jr., age 82 of Pompano Beach, passed away December 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Beatrice, loving father of Grover M. Moscowitz III and wife Rachel, James F. Moscowitz and wife Tina Redecha. Dear brother of Alva Hammel, Marion Rosmarin & Warren S. Moss. Practicing attorney, Executive Vice President downtown Brooklyn Community
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MOSCOWITZ, GROVER M.

body: When plans were announced for a 12-screen multiplex and a Barnes & Noble bookstore in downtown Brooklyn, the project seemed like a case study in urban rebirth. It would rise on a gritty block of Court Street, an ugly hole in the ground that was once the site of a theater that showed pornographic movies. For years, residents in Brooklyn Heights had
title: Lights, Camera, Lots of Action; Multiplex Plan Raises Concerns in Brooklyn Heights

body: They came by airplane and bus and automobile. They came dressed in their navy blues with their hats on. Some brought their sons to the funeral today. Snapping flags at half-staff lined the route for the funeral cortege in this small western Long Island town. Lieut. Joseph P. Cavalieri was the last of three New York City firefighters to be buried
title: Dressed in Their Blues, To Say a Final Goodbye

body: WHAT do a monoprint of a chicken, a wood and fabric sculpture of a woman holding a dodo bird and a charcoal drawing of the West Side Highway have in common? All are original works in two shows sponsored by the Brooklyn Arts Council. The ''Printmakers' Portfolio'' is a selection of several hundred prints by internationally known artists as well as
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS/DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Printmakers Great and Small

author: Jason DeParle, a staff writer for the magazine, has written extensively on welfare reform.
body: One Saturday morning this fall, a 54-year-old Bronx woman who has spent more years on welfare than she can remember answered a small-type summons from the city government, the second that she has received this year. ''Dear Sir/Madam,'' it began. ''You are being called in to evaluate your employability.'' She stuffed two doctors' letters into a worn
title: What Welfare-to-Work Really Means

body: THE QE2 was docked at Casablanca in 1989 when Jeanie Bowers Scott, then performing on board as an opera singer, received a call from her husband, George. ''I bought a building for $13 million,'' he said, ''and when you get back we are moving in with a bunch of college students.'' The Scotts did indeed move into 521 West 49th Street with 176
title: A Niche Business: Dorms for New York Students

body: THE reports of a fire on Vandalia Avenue in Brooklyn jolted Ricco Sanchez into reality. Forget the near-numbing talk about Presidential impeachment or the almost emotionless descriptions of the smart bombs and surgical strikes in Baghdad. Fire? That's big news in Mr. Sanchez's part of the world. His grandmother lives on Vandalia Avenue, and he
title: About New York; Fire Shows That All Pain Starts at Home

body: To identify abused children before they are seriously or fatally injured at home, the Board of Education will introduce a new unit next week to track student absenteeism and tardiness. The creation of the unit is Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's first tangible step toward turning the spotlight on a problem that has dogged the system for years:
title: Schools Create Unit to Track Absenteeism

body: IT'S another weekday afternoon rush hour in lower Manhattan, and Canal Street is gridlocked. Eastbound lanes are clogged with cars, trucks and buses headed for the Manhattan Bridge. Westbound lanes are choked with vehicles aiming for the Holland Tunnel. On northbound and southbound arteries -- Hudson and Varick Streets, the West Side Highway, even
title: JAMMING; The Traffic Downtown Seems Worse Than Ever. Is the Verrazano the Villain?

body: For years, University Towers, the 549-unit, three-building cooperative half a block east of downtown Brooklyn's Metrotech Center, has struggled with sluggish sales and low prices. But in recent months, the fortunes of the 5.5-acre gated community have been turning around. This year, 50 of the 379 sponsor-held units at the complex, from studios to
title: Residential Real Estate; Rejuvenated Area Stirs Co-op Sales in Complex

body: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by Paul Griffiths, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations. More recommendations for this weekend are
title: Merrily on High: Musical Pleasures of the Holiday Season

body: The parent who set off the furor in a Brooklyn school over the use of the book ''Nappy Hair'' said yesterday that she remained unconvinced of the book's merits for classroom use. The woman, Cathy Wright, said that one day last month, she was sorting through papers in her 8-year-old's book bag when she stumbled upon photocopied pages with what
title: Unswayed by Debate on Children's Book

body: For years, dreams of creating Hollywood-on-the-Hudson have tantalized politicians and entrepreneurs, only to collide with the financial realities of a high-risk industry. In recent months, it looked as if those dreams might finally be realized, as several entrepreneurs announced plans for complexes of sound stages like the studio back lots in Los
title: Tinseltown Dreams Face Reality

body: A community meeting in Brooklyn last night for the author of the book ''Nappy Hair'' turned combative when some people said the book was derogatory and questioned its use in a third-grade classroom. The hourlong event, held at the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in downtown Brooklyn, was an effort to bridge the gap between people who approve
title: Author of Disputed Book Is Criticized in Brooklyn

body: Parents and teachers at a Queens school welcomed a white teacher yesterday who transferred after her use of a book, ''Nappy Hair,'' at a Brooklyn school caused some parents to threaten her. Last week, the teacher, Ruth A. Sherman, transferred to Public School 131 in Jamaica from P.S. 75 in Bushwick after some parents publicly threatened ''to get''
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Teacher Is Welcomed After Book Dispute

body: The windows in the hulking building on Flatbush Avenue Extension were once walled off, back when it housed Steam Heat, an all-nude nightclub that closed in the summer of 1996 after a lengthy legal battle. Now Carlos E. Russell, a former Brooklyn College dean, has unblocked the windows in his effort to turn the former home of the strip joint into a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; At Former Strip Club, Black Culture May Take the Stage

body: Nancy A. Slahetka felt fear in the pit of her stomach as she read a letter from her alma mater, Brooklyn Law School, last month. The letter said the school would be changing its loan-assistance program for graduates who pursue low-paying public interest work. After doing some math, a desolate Ms. Slahetka realized that her $386 monthly loan payment
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Law Students Keep Bargain Loan Deal

body: A white third-grade teacher who was threatened by two black parents after she used the book ''Nappy Hair'' in her Brooklyn classroom started a new assignment in a Queens school yesterday, school officials said. The teacher, Ruth A. Sherman, began teaching a second-grade class at Public School 131 in Jamaica, in Community School District 29, a
title: Teacher in Book Dispute Starts New Job in Queens School

body: Jenette Parks was confused. On Tuesday afternoon the hot dog cart she usually patronizes was no longer in front of New York City Technical College on Jay Street. Instead, it was around the corner on Tillary Street. ''You moved over here now,'' Ms. Parks told the hot dog vendor, Michael Papakostas. He sighed. ''The police chased me,'' he said.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; College Fixture Must Roll On

body: QUICK! Where can you find a 1959 Girl Scout handbook, the first book in English about dogs or a Butterick sewing pattern from 1900? Try one of New York's hundreds of little specialized libraries, where materials like these abound but not a single book by Stephen King is in sight. Special libraries, as they are called, employ 1,400 librarians in the
title: MAKING IT WORK; Narrow Shelves, Depths of Knowledge

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE CITY POLITIC; From Video Store to Pizza Cafe, a Senator in Their Midst

body: Entering the United States Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn, you see the trappings common to a court lobby: metal detector, security guards, pictures of President Clinton and Vice President Gore. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Camera Links U.S. Judge to Rural Romania

The man, James Smith, 29, was arrested on Friday afternoon in Freeport, N.Y., Nassau County Police Department officials said, after a 15-year-old girl
title: Rape Suspect In 4 Attacks Is in Custody

body: When the Brooklyn Academy of Music opens its new cinema tomorrow after four days of previews and a ribbon-cutting party tonight, a lot more will be riding on it than the mere fate of the borough's first art-house movie theater. The BAM Rose Cinemas, created by the architect Hugh Hardy, who carved up the little-used Carey Playhouse in the academy's
title: More Than Just a Movie House; A Magnet for Brooklyn's Young Is in Place, but Will It Work?

title: GOOD EATING; Dining Preludes For Show at BAM

body: Could it be a romantic evocation of a medieval sewer system? Or is it a health hazard? Dr. Peter Homel mulls these questions daily at the Atlantic Avenue subway station in downtown Brooklyn as a pipe sends a stream of malodorous water along the tracks of the Manhattan-bound D and Q trains. ''It smells like a pissoir,'' said Dr. Homel, a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK YUCK; Oui, They Agree the Subway Isn't a French Lavender Field

title: MAKING IT WORK; Underdogs of the Kitchen

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Career Criminal Is Suspect in Three Rapes

title: 16 Are Charged in Bribery Scheme at Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn

body: The new Federal courthouse that opened for business on a spectacular waterfront site here this week is in many ways the first of its kind in modern judicial architecture: a building designed to welcome rather than intimidate, to invite the public to stop by for a meal, an art exhibit, a film festival, a chamber music concert or a stroll through the
title: Hear Ye! Hear Ye! See Ye, Too!

body: PERHAPS no other profession touches so many New Yorkers' lives but is as unregulated as that of building superintendent. Many trades have exams and licenses, but the only hint in New York City law that supers even exist is a requirement that buildings with 16 or more units have a janitor on or within 200 feet of the premises 24 hours a day. The law
title: MAKING IT WORK; Supers Trade Tips and Tales of Woe

title: CALENDAR

body: Twelve years ago, Stacey G. Maher became a rookie New York City police officer despite warnings from a cousin who was a seasoned police supervisor. ''He told me it was a horrible job for women,'' she recalled. ''Every day at work you will be talked about, sized up and dissected like a frog in a lab.'' Officer Maher now ruefully says that the
title: Lawsuits Depict a Police Culture of Sexual Harassment and Cover-Ups

body: The police said yesterday that a man who raped a woman on a G train in Brooklyn on Sept. 5 is a serial rapist who attacked a teen-age girl and at least one other woman in similar situations this month and raped another woman earlier this year. The suspect is described as a black man about 25 years old, 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighing about 200
title: Police in Brooklyn Seek Serial Rapist In Subway Assaults

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN -- BUZZ; Put on That Tiara and Do the Electric Slide

body: Ever-rising construction costs, driven by the resumption of large-scale development in New York City, have delayed and may fundamentally alter plans for a new 18-story Federal courthouse in downtown Brooklyn. The courthouse, planned at Cadman Plaza East and Tillary Street, has already been designed. The General Services Administration received
title: Soaring Costs Delay Building of Federal Courthouse

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Yeltsin's New Choice Is a Compromise Candidate President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia bowed out of a confrontation with his emboldened opposition and named Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov as his compromise candidate to head a new government. The nomination of the veteran diplomat and spymaster was welcomed by a range of
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: PICHONA ETLIS and three friends traveled from Argentina to New York for a quick getaway. They had already ridden the double-decker tour buses for one of those quickie pseudosurveys of the city. Downtown and uptown, they had shopped and dined, walked and watched. It was all nice, but was it real? Something was missing. Brooklyn. The borough on the
title: About New York; Over a Bridge, The Real Life Of Nueva York

body: After years of chronic difficulty attracting qualified teachers to the nation's largest school system, New York City education officials say they have hired 5,000 teachers in one of the most competitive hiring seasons in recent memory -- enough to fill virtually every classroom when the city's 1,100 public schools open tomorrow. Beyond its widely
title: Few Teacher Vacancies as New York City Recruits 5,000 to Schools

body: It took 15 years, from when the first plans were drawn up in 1983 until tenants started moving in earlier this year, to turn Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza from a concept into a reality. But now it is there, its front on Adams Street in the borough's downtown district and complete with 820,000 square feet of Class A office space, a 376-room Marriott
title: Commercial Real Estate; Assembling Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza Puzzle

body: BACK in Trinidad, a half century ago, Ortner Murray ''never dreamed'' that some day he might actually own property. The only real estate Mr. Murray knew anything about then were the acres that he and his 11 brothers and sisters worked alongside their father, a sharecropper, urging bananas, coconuts and corn from earth entitled to an English
title: Providing Places to Work, Places to Live

body: SOON after arriving in New York, Marjon Rivera fell into his morning routine. On weekdays, shortly before 7 A.M., he stops at a small chapel on the corner of Pine and William Streets, in the heart of the financial district. Burnished light falls through stained-glass windows. About a dozen other Wall Street workers, dressed like Mr. Rivera in suits
title: The Streets Are Paved With PC's; Wall Street and Silicon Alley Lure a New Breed of High-Tech Immigrants

Their common thread was the man who had either engineered the campaigns or produced strategies to derail them. For the two dozen or so former
title: Gathering of Old-School Politicians Mourns a Master of the Craft

body: Representatives of Swiss commercial banks and Holocaust survivors announced a settlement yesterday in which the banks agreed to pay $1.25 billion in restitution to victims of the Nazi era. The agreement, intended to settle the claims of tens of thousands of survivors whose families lost assets in World War II, was hailed by Jewish groups and
title: SWISS BANKS REACH HOLOCAUST ACCORD

body: Anthony J. Genovesi, a State Assemblyman and powerful political force in Brooklyn Democratic politics for two decades, was killed on Monday night in a one-car accident about 50 miles north of New York City. Mr. Genovesi, 61, and his 26-year-old daughter, Lara, were returning from a family home in the Berkshires when the car, driven by his daughter,
title: Anthony Genovesi, Legislator, Dies at 61 in a One-Car Crash

body: A child welfare supervisor was arrested yesterday when he tried to walk into the Brooklyn Family Court building with 31 small plastic bags of marijuana, city officials said. The supervisor, Israel Rodriguez, 39, was supposed to examine computers in the courthouse, at 283 Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn. But court officers, who followed routine by
title: Marijuana Charges at Family Court

body: A 1915 warehouse overlooking the Brooklyn waterfront that had been used as an office building in the last decade is now being converted into condominium lofts, offering views of the East River and the Manhattan skyline. The $30 million conversion of the Clock Tower Building at One Main Street is the latest step in the slow transformation of the
title: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE; A Neighborhood Called Dumbo Has High Hopes

Catacosinos. ''Our being here together today is a good beginning,'' said Marketspan's new
title: Power Board To Seek Deal On Severance

body: THE Brooklyn Historical Society created a stir nine years ago by installing large photographic cutouts of Ralph Kramden and Ebbets Field and a model of the Coney Island Cyclone in its landmarked 1880 building in Brooklyn Heights. In a place where Brooklynese was hardly spoken, these icons of popular culture seemed brash. But lately the society has
title: MAKING IT WORK; Not Just Knickknacks, but What?

Catacosinos, is negotiating the terms of his resignation, company officials said today. One high-ranking official with close ties to Dr. Catacosinos said the chairman's resignation could
title: UTILITY EXECUTIVE IN TALKS TO RESIGN

body: An article last Sunday about courthouse construction misstated the scope of renovation planned at the United States Post Office and Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn. Four courtrooms in the building are to be restored, not two.
title: Corrections

body: A Palestinian immigrant who testified that he had wanted to kill as many Jews as possible in a suicide attack was convicted yesterday of plotting to explode a powerful pipe bomb in the New York City subway. But in a case that raised the specter of another terrorist attack in a city where the World Trade Center was bombed five years ago, the jury in
title: Jury Convicts Man in Scheme To Set a Bomb In the Subway

body: With a leasing program nearing completion in downtown Flushing, the Muss Development Company of Queens is confirming the need for modern service-oriented office space in commercial centers outside Manhattan. And as Muss pursues other projects in Brooklyn and Queens, it is also demonstrating the virtues of patience in development work. Remember
title: Commercial Real Estate; Plaza Heeding Call for More Offices

body: PICTURE a courthouse rotunda: sanctuary of law, cynosure of the community. Now pull it out of the building and set it in front, as an entrance. Taper it, tilt its central axis 3 1/2 degrees and top it with four square fins. Clad it in a sleek white sheath. More than an abstraction, this rotunda is becoming a towering reality in the middle of Long
title: Putting a New Face on Justice

body: In a sign that developers are increasingly forced to scout out unlikely locales for new projects, a Manhattan company said yesterday that it would build a huge entertainment complex along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn that would include the city's largest multiplex movie theater. title: Theater Complex Planned for Brooklyn

body: A Federal agent testified yesterday that a man charged with plotting to explode a powerful pipe bomb in a New York City subway told him that he had wanted to bomb a rush-hour train on the B line ''because there are a lot of Jews that ride that train.'' The defendant, Ghazi Ibrahim Abu Maizar, is one of two Palestinian immigrants on trial on charges
title: Defendant Told of Plan To Use Bomb, Agent Says

title: Commercial Property/Bruce Ratner; Meeting the Demand for Stores Outside Manhattan

body: One day last week, about 20 Orthodox Jews, about half of them ultra-Orthodox Hasidim, stood in a hallway in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and, with ritualistic nods and sways and a collective hum as they murmured their prayer, conducted an afternoon service. Later, some of them drifted into a nearby courtroom and stared at the two men on trial
title: Reporter's Notebook; Worlds Intermingle at Juxtaposed Criminal Trials in Brooklyn

body: The blue fliers began appearing in the middle of last month, on university campuses and in hiring halls from Vienna to Salzburg to Innsbruck. title: Low on Teachers, New York Scours Austria

body: On the first workday that they were on sale, the new transit passes that offer unlimited rides on the city's subways and buses caused long lines at some token booths yesterday and minor confusion throughout the system. But over all, transit officials said, the new passes were a success. Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said
title: M.T.A. Sees Unlimited-Ride Metrocard as Workaday Success

body: In Manhattan, sure. But Brooklyn? Still, there they are, those big red double-decker tourist buses chugging past Fulton Landing, around Grand Army Plaza and in the shadow of the sleek, 376-room Marriott that is to open Tuesday as Brooklyn's first large new hotel in 68 years. ''Everybody has heard something about Brooklyn,'' said Claudia Pongratz, a
title: A Nice Place to Visit; A Hotel! Bus Tours! Brooklyn Hits the Tourist Map

body: One picture of Lafi Khalil and Ghazi Ibrahim Abu Maizar is of two young Palestinian men who were drifters in Brooklyn, living hand-to-mouth on short-term jobs and ogling women on the street, but hardly terrorists ready to kill for a cause. Another picture is of two men who were hours or days away from exploding a powerful pipe bomb in New York
title: Conflicting Portraits of Bomb Suspects

body: Parents are forever trying to teach their children that sharing toys is good. But such generosity can also yield health benefits. So a Cobble Hill couple are founding one of the region's few toy libraries, to help ill infants who are economically disadvantaged. Pauline's Library is to open as part of the Infant and Child Learning Center at Kings
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS; A Library for Toy Therapy

body: THE peculiar 1892 house at 217 82d Street, between Third Avenue and Ridge Boulevard, has one of Bay Ridge's most unusual interiors. Now a local preservation group is afraid the sophisticated shingle-style building is just a ''tear-down'' in danger of being sold and replaced by town houses. The owner says he is only offering it to families, but in
title: Streetscapes/217 82d Street, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; 1892 Shingle-Style House With an Unusual Layout

body: FOR most of the 18 years since Adib Abdelshahed emigrated to New York from Egypt, he and several friends felt like nomads as they searched for a place to worship. They had two requirements: it had to be a Lutheran church and the service had to be in Arabic. On most Sundays, Mr. Abdelshahed said, they found themselves in small rooms or the basement
title: MAKING IT WORK; In the Steps of Martin Luther, in Arabic

body: The dismissal of Mildred Rosario would seem to be clear cut. A substitute public school teacher in the Bronx, Ms. Rosario readily admitted to school officials that she had led her sixth graders in prayer on June 8, asking ''if anyone would like to accept Jesus as their Saviour'' and then laying her hands on their foreheads. The Board of Education
title: Teacher Is Now Political Cause After Dismissal For Class Prayer

body: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted last night to allow landlords to raise rents by 2 percent when tenants renewed leases for one year and 4 percent when they renewed for two years, a compromise that the board has made several times in the last decade to try to appease tenants and landlords. title: Rent Board Votes Increases of 2% and 4%

body: A 19-year-old Queens man charged with unleashing a hail of gunfire that wounded eight people at a downtown Brooklyn mall last week was released from custody yesterday after his lawyer produced a videotape that appears to show the man was in Queens when the shootings occurred. Prosecutors did not drop the charges against the suspect, Ramon Cable,
title: Doubt Cast on Arrest Of Man in Shootings

body: Police detectives have arrested a Queens teen-ager who they said is a member of the Bloods street gang on charges that he shot eight pedestrians in downtown Brooklyn after becoming irritated by a girl's request to leave the gang. The man charged, Ramon Cable, 19, was taken into custody Tuesday night near his home on Beach Street in Rockaway,
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Queens Man Arrested In Brooklyn Shootings

body: In yesterday's summertime sun, the Fulton Mall buzzed to the tune of money: as the third busiest shopping district in the city, it trails only Herald Square and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. title: Shooting Spotlights Troubled Side of a Brooklyn Mall

body: A hail of gunfire that left eight people wounded at a downtown Brooklyn mall Monday night may have been the result of a gang-related dispute, the police said yesterday. A man was being questioned last night in connection with the shooting, but he had not been arrested, said Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman. The gunman opened fire at 7
title: Police Suspect Gang Dispute in Shooting

body: Six women and two men were wounded by gunfire last evening when a gunman, apparently fighting with an acquaintance, burst out of a clothing store and began shooting into a crowded pedestrian plaza in the heart of downtown Brooklyn, the police said. Shoppers and passers-by dispersed or ducked for cover as bullets sprayed through the air about 7 P.M.
title: Eight People Are Wounded by Gunfire at a Downtown Brooklyn Mall

author: Mimi Sheraton is a former restaurant critic for The New York Times. Her latest book is ''Food Markets of the World'' (Abrams).
body: It has always seemed both exciting and practical to take a sightseeing bus tour through a strange city, as I have done many times. But a bus tour through my lost youth? title: Touring the Heart's Own Brooklyn

title: CHANCELLOR VOWS TO FAIL STUDENTS LACKING IN SKILLS

body: BACK when East New York seemed more like West Hell, Betty Peterson-Williams heard of new homes sprouting up there and in Brownsville. title: About New York; A Project Called Hope, Unrealized

body: Six hundred nurses went on strike yesterday at Maimonides Medical Center, demonstrating in force outside Brooklyn's second-largest hospital in an angry picket line that reverberated with cries of strong-arm management tactics. title: Nurses Strike Maimonides Center In Deadlock Over Cuts in Benefits

title: Henny Youngman, King of the One-Liners, Is Dead at 91 After 6 Decades of Laughter

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
